title: Merkel launches operation AKK — again
text:
BERLIN — Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer and Angela Merkel have done it again.

Just when it looked as if the leader of the Christian Democratic Union’s political future was dimming, she and the German chancellor risked a high-stakes, high-reward maneuver by snatching control of the defense ministry, one of the country’s most powerful political offices.

In the process they outflanked their male rivals, bolstering Kramp-Karrenbauer’s chances of succeeding Merkel as chancellor.

For the second time in just two weeks — the first being former Defense Minister Ursula von der Leyen’s surprise elevation to the Commission presidency — the sheer audacity of Germany’s Frauenpower left the country’s political class gobsmacked.

If the playbook sounds familiar, that’s because Kramp-Karrenbauer (with more than a little help from Merkel) pulled off a similar feat last December in her run to succeed her mentor as leader of the Christian Democrats, besting a tough challenger at a party convention with a barnstorming eleventh-hour speech that secured her victory by a narrow margin.

In the months that followed, however, Kramp-Karrenbauer’s political fortunes soured as the Christian Democrats recorded their worst-ever European election result. The party has lost substantial ground to the Greens, whose environmental message is increasingly resonating at a time of growing voter concern about climate change. The Greens, who won less than 10 percent of the vote in the last national election in 2017, are now neck-and-neck with the conservatives in most polls.

While the CDU’s decline is not all Kramp-Karrenbauer’s doing, she didn’t help matters by accusing a group of young YouTube personalities in the wake of the European election of trying to “destroy” her party with an anti-CDU campaign. She also suggested it might be necessary to regulate such content during election campaigns, sparking accusations that she wanted to censor political speech.

Kramp-Karrenbauer’s troubled start as party leader renewed questions about her suitability for the chancellery, reviving speculation that one of her challengers for the party’s leadership, Health Minister Jens Spahn or Friedrich Merz, a CDU veteran with strong backing in conservative circles, could end up succeeding Merkel instead.

Within the CDU, party strategists argued that Kramp-Karrenbauer, who has never served in the Cabinet, should take on a major ministry to prove she has what it takes to lead Germany.

Whether by chance or design, von der Leyen’s nomination to become Commission president handed Kramp-Karrenbauer the break she needed.

It was von der Leyen’s failure to effectively reform the troubled [defense] ministry during her six-year tenure that took her out of consideration as Merkel’s successor.

In what now looks like a clever diversionary tactic meant to draw attention away from the broader implications of von der Leyen’s nomination, Kramp-Karrenbauer insisted that she had no intention of becoming defense minister or accepting any other Cabinet position.

“I made a clear decision to leave a government position for a party position,” Kramp-Karrenbauer, who was premier of the Saarland region before becoming CDU chief, told the Bild daily earlier this month. “There’s a lot to do in the CDU.”

Given Kramp-Karrenbauer’s apparent decision to pass on the job, attention shifted to other possible candidates, in particular Spahn, a rising CDU star who has received high marks across the aisle for his management of the health ministry.

For Spahn, who has made no secret of his ambition to become chancellor, the defense ministry would have been a perfect stepping stone to the chancellery. With a budget of more than €40 billion and oversight of Germany’s 180,000 soldiers, the defense ministry is the perfect proving ground for would-be chancellors.

Indeed, it was von der Leyen’s failure to effectively reform the troubled ministry during her six-year tenure that took her out of consideration as Merkel’s successor.

While some see the defense minister position as a poisoned chalice, there may have never been a more propitious moment to take on the job.

Von der Leyen is widely blamed for the military’s woes, and no one believes fixing the problems will be easy. With just over two years left in the government’s current term, the bar for success is low. The low expectations should make it easier for the new minister to shine in parliament and on the international stage.

“Many servicemen and women want a minister who is interested in the job itself and not looking to use it as a springboard to the next-higher position” —Tobias Lindner, a Green member of the German parliament’s defense committee

That dynamic explains both Kramp-Karrenbauer’s interest in the position and her decision with Merkel to keep the plan under wraps until after von der Leyen was approved by the European Parliament on Tuesday.

Their success in keeping the move a secret is a testament to the power of Merkel’s inner circle. As late as Tuesday evening, many in the party were convinced Spahn would get the nod. Some German media even reported that Spahn would be sworn in on Wednesday.

Then, late Tuesday, Merkel’s spokesman shocked political Berlin with the announcement that it would be Kramp-Karrenbauer instead.

In addition to giving Kramp-Karrenbauer a more prominent platform, the defense ministry should help her step out of Merkel’s shadow. As party leader, Kramp-Karrenbauer didn’t even hold a seat in parliament, making it difficult for her to shed her reputation as nothing more than a “mini-Merkel,” as her critics suggest.

Nonetheless, the political calculation behind Kramp-Karrenbauer’s move could end up backfiring if she fails to win the confidence of rank-and-file members of the military.

Merkel is keen to avoid handing power to either Spahn or Merz, men with whom she has a long history of clashes.

“Many servicemen and women want a minister who is interested in the job itself and not looking to use it as a springboard to the next-higher position,” said Tobias Lindner, a Green member of the German parliament’s defense committee.

For Merkel, there’s a more compelling reason to elevate her chosen successor. Though the chancellor has insisted she intends to remain in office until the end of the current legislative term in 2021, she always qualified that pledge with the caveat that she would only do so if her health enabled her to.

A series of recent shaking spells, the cause of which Merkel hasn’t divulged, has raised questions about whether her health is sound enough for her to serve the full term.

While persistent tensions with the Social Democrats, Merkel’s coalition partner, have led many to predict the government’s collapse before year’s end, the governing parties’ poor poll numbers suggest they will hold on for as long as they can.

That’s why Kramp-Karrenbauer’s new position could prove to be more significant than may appear at first glance. Merkel is keen to avoid handing power to either Spahn or Merz, men with whom she has a long history of clashes.

Bolstered by her new status as minister, Kamp-Karrenbauer would be in pole position to take over as chancellor without a new election for the rest of the term — if the Bundestag approves her.

In other words, Merkel has all but guaranteed her ability to determine not just the timing of her exit, but her preferred successor as well.

The chancellor, who turned 65 on Wednesday, could hardly have hoped for a better birthday gift.

CORRECTED: This article has been amended to clarify the circumstances under which Kramp-Karrenbauer could take over as chancellor.
description: First they took Brussels, then they took Berlin: German Frauenpower leaves the political class gobsmacked.
